 	 • Contributing Factors: search for and treat possible contributing factors. Fluid boluses for h ypovolemia should be calculated using LBT 

 	 • Blood Glucose Level: If blood glucose level < 60, refer to Hypoglycemia & Hyperglycemia Clinical Care Guideline. 

 	 • Observe patient’s sensorium and airway during postictal period. Consider etiology and refer to Altered Mental Status Clinical Care Guideline. 

 	 • Place nothing in mouth during seizure. 

 III. Midazolam 0.1 mg/kg IVP, IM or Intra-nasal with max does of 5 mg 

 IV. Physician Orders: Contact Medical Control if seizure activity continues.

I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Length-Based Tape: measure child to determine weight and color zone. Select equipment as indicated by color zone on the Length-Based Tape. 

 	 • Initial Medical Care: assess and support ABCs as needed. Significant attempts should be made to keep child calm at all times; including allowing parents close contact with patient during transport. 

 	 • Oxygen: via Pediatric mask or "blow-by" technique. If respiratory failure is imminent, use BVMR and ventilate with Oxygen @ 15 LPM. 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Capnography: apply nasal cannula Filter Line. 

 Supportive Care: 

 	 • Humidified Oxygen: with 3 ml of NS via blow-by. 

 	 • Albuterol: 2.5 mg via blow-by, if effective may repeat x 2. Indications: bronchial constriction and/or wheezing. 

 	 • If no response, Albuterol 2.5 mg and Atrovent0.5 mg combined via updraft blow-by. 

 Impending Respiratory Failure: 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV of NS KVO. 

 	 • Solu-Medrol: 2 mg/kg IV (max total dose 125 mg). Indications: moderate to severe obstruction refractory to beta-agonists. 

 	 • Advanced Airway: Endotracheal tube. Do not attempt aggressive airway intervention unless airway becomes obstructed. Use an ET tube one size smaller than the recommended size according to the Length-Based Tape. If the patient is physiologically difficult to intubate (severe anxiety, etc.) refer to Difficult Airway - Facilitated Intubation Guideline. 

 	 • Needle Cricothyrotomy Indications: Unable to ventilate effectively after above attempts.

I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Initial Medical Care. Place patient in their position of comfort. 

 	 • Length-Based Tape: measure child to determine weight and color zone. Select antiarrhythmic dosages and equipment as indicated by color zone on the Length-Based Tape. If Length-Based Tape not available, calculate dosages using weight-based dosages listed below. 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Treat Underlying Cause: assess and treat suspected cause if sinus tachycardia (See Notes). 

 	 • Vagal Maneuvers: perform Valsalva maneuver or apply cool moisture to face. 

 	 • Antiarrhythmic Agents: 

 		 i. Adenosine: first dose of 0.1 mg/kg Rapid IVP (maximum 1st dose of 6 mg). If no conversion, second dose: 0.2 mg/kg Rapid IVP (maximum 2nd dose of 12 mg). Indications: stable patients with narrow-complex tachycardia. 

 		 ii. Amiodarone: 5 mg/kg IV drip (bolus over 20 minutes) (max single dose of 300 mg) 

 Indications: stable patients with wide-complex tachycardia. 

 		 iii. Physician\’s Consult: contact Medical Control for alternative treatments if above antiarrhythmic agents are unsuccessful in rhythm conversion or rate control. 

 	 • Synchronized Cardioversion: 1 J/kg 

 		 Indications: unstable patients with inadequate perfusion. 

 		 i. Consider pre-medication with Midazolam: 0.1 mg/kg IV or Intra-nasal, repeat every 3-5 minutes until adequate relaxation / sedation is achieved prior to procedure (max total dosage 4 mg). Use Midazolam with caution in the presence of hypotension. 

 		 ii. If rhythm does not convert, escalate energy level to 2 J/kg for Subsequent SYNCHRONIZED CARDIOVERSIONS 

 		 iii. If delays in synchronization occur and clinical condition is critical, proceed immediately to unsynchronized shocks i.e. defibrillation 

 NOTES: 

 1. Sinus tachycardia: p-waves present and normal, usually has variable RR intervals (varies during respirations and agitation), and constant PR interval.
Infants: HR usually < 220 bpm. \n Children: HR usually < 180 bpm.
2. SVT or narrow-complex tachycardia: p-waves absent / abnormal, RR intervals not variable, and history of abrupt rate changes.
Infants: HR usually > 220 bpm. \n Children: HR usually > 180 bpm.

I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Length-Based Tape: measure child to determine weight and color zone. Select RESUSCITATION medication dosages and equipment as indicated by color zone on the Length-Based Tape. If Length-Based Tape not available, calculate dosages using weight-based dosages. 

 Cardiac Arrest Management: 	 • Assess patient using Primary ABCD Survey and perform appropriate action following American Heart Association (AHA) CPR Guidelines. 

 	 • If using an AED, follow the manufacturer's prompts for cardiac arrest management (use pediatric AED system if available for children 1 to 8 years of age). 

 	 • Follow End Of Life Administrative Policy, as necessary. 

 	 • If arrest > 4 minutes: perform 2 minutes of CPR prior to assessing rhythm. 

 	 • If arrest < 4-minutes or witnessed: assess rhythm. 

 	 •Defibrillation: 2 J / kg x 1 shock. 

 				 i. Non-organized rhythm: start CPR. 

 				 ii. Organized rhythm: check pulse < 10 seconds. If no radial pulse or unsure, perform 2 minutes of CPR and then reassess. 

 	 • Reassess rhythm after every 2-minute period of CPR. 

 	 • If shock-able rhythm persists, use 4 J / kg for subsequent shocks. 

 	 • Treatment Sequence: Prepare next drug prior to rhythm check. Administer drug during CPR, as soon as possible after the rhythm check confirms VF/pulseless VT. Do not delay shock. Continue CPR while drugs are prepared and administered and defibrillator is charging. Ideally, chest compressions should be interrupted only for ventilation (until advanced airway placed), rhythm check, and shock delivery 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 Resuscitation: 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV/IO of NS KVO. 

 	 • Epinephrine 1:10,000: 0.01 mg/kg IV/10. Repeat every 3-5 minutes of continued arrest. 

 	 • Antiarrhythmic Agents: repeated every 3-5 minutes of continued arrest 

 		 i. Amiodarone: 5 mg/kg IV/IO, repeat x 2 doses (max single dose of 300 mg) 

 		 ii. Magnesium Sulfate: 50 mg/kg slow IVP/IO over 5 minutes mixed in 10 ml 

 NS (maximum total dose 2 grams). Indications: torsades de pointes 

 	 • Advanced Airway 

 	 • Contributing Factors: search for and treat 6 H's & 5 T's. If hypovolemia known or suspected, administer fluid boluses as calculated by Length-Based Tape (20 ml/kg). Max 3 boluses 

 Post-resuscitation Maintenance Therapy: 

 	 • Amiodarone: 5 mg/kg IV/IO drip over 20 minutes (maximum single dose 300 mg) Indications: If rhythm converts prior to antiarrhythmic agent. 

 	 • Midazolam: 0.1 mg/kg IV/IO or Intra-nasal, repeat every 5 minutes (maximum total dose 4 mg) (6). Indications: combative post resuscitation patients. Use Midazolam with caution in the presence or hypotension. 

 III. Refer to Post-resuscitation Management Clinical Care Guideline

I. .Deliver infant according to Childbirth (Emergency) Clinical Care Guideline. 
 	 • Record TIME of delivery. 
 	 • Record APGAR score at 1 and 5 minutes. 

 II. Continue to suction mouth FIRST, then nose of infant with bulb syringe. Meconium-stained infants should not be stimulated to breathe until suctioning has occurred: 
 	 • Suction only upon delivery of the head PRIOR to delivery of the baby. 
 	 • After delivery, INTUBATE infant and apply suction to the lumen of the ETT while withdrawing from the trachea. Following intubation, confirm proper tube placement by auscultating the gastric area and the lungs bilaterally, and noting positive change on the end-tidal CO2 detector. 

 III. Continually assess respiratory rate.

IV. Assess heart rate.

 	 • If the heart rate is < 100 beats per minute, positive-pressure ventilations with 100% oxygen should be initiated immediately. 
 	 • If the heart rate is < 60 beats per minute or 60 to 80 beats per minute and not increasing rapidly despite effective ventilation with 100% oxygen, CHEST COMPRESSIONS SHOULD BE INITIATED.

string.name: parameter_newborn_tb1r1c2
string.b: If Respirations Shallow, Slow, Or Absent:

resources.string: Place infant on side in Trendelenburg position.
Assist ventilations with OXYGEN @ 100/u0025 via BVM.
Assess color and provide OXYGEN @ 100/u0025 via NRB mask if central cyanosis present.
If respirations improve, provide OXYGEN @ 100/u0025 via NRB mask.

I. VENOMUS/POISONOUS 

 	 • Initial Medical / Trauma Care. Contact law enforcement. 

 	 • Irrigate and cleanse wound with saline. 

 	 • Assess degree of bite or sting by measuring bite / sting marks. Outline edematous, erythemic and ecchymotic areas with pen, and note time. 

 	 • Apply constricting band if ETA to initial receiving facility is > 20 minutes. Apply constricting band proximal to wound if insect or snake bite / sting shows signs of increasing reaction. Ensure constricting band does not impede arterial blood flow. 

 	 • Keep patient supine and calm. Immobilize affected part. Remove distal jewelry. 

 	 • Remove stingers; if present, taking care to avoid compression. 

 	 • Identify animal that caused bite or sting. 

 	 • Do not apply ice or cold pack to snake bites or marine stings 

 	 • Bring the dead animal to the hospital, if able. Do not try to catch the animal if it is still alive. 

 II. TRAUMATIC 

 	 • Initial Medical / Trauma Care. 

 	 • Cleanse area around wounds. 

 	 • Dry sterile dressing to wounds. 

 	 • Treat per applicable Clinical Care Guideline. 


NOTES Contact the American Association of Poison Control Centers, through the Communications Center or by calling 1-800-222-1222, to obtain information regarding the initial stabilization and management of the exposure. The American Association of Poison Control Centers will assume responsibility and provide home management and follow-up per their standard operating protocols as required by Florida Statutes 

 Patients presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with anaphylaxis must be treated with the appropriate Clinical Care Guideline.

INHALATION BURNS 

 I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Note presence of wheezing, hoarseness, stridor, carbonaceous sputum / cough, singed nasal hair, eyebrows / lashes or respiratory distress. 

 	 • BVMR: Assist ventilations if respiratory insufficiency is evident. 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Initial Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached 

 	 • Intubation: Consider early intubation if the above respiratory involvement signs are present. If early intubation is warranted or the patient is physiologically difficult to intubate (severe anxiety, etc.), refer to Difficult Airway-Facilitated Intubation Guideline for sedation. 

 ELECTRICAL BURNS 

 I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Establish scene safety. Have electrical source turned off. Immobilize as indicated. 

 	 • Assess for entry and exit wounds. Assess neurovascular status of affected part. 

 	 • Cover wounds with dry sterile dressings (cooling not necessary). 

 	 • Spinal immobilization if high voltage electrical injuries (>1000 Volts, excluding Taser) 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Initial Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached 

 	 • Assess ECG for arrhythmias and refer to appropriate Clinical Care Guideline. 

 	 • Refer to Pain Management Clinical Care Guideline. 

 CHEMICAL BURNS 

 I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Primary decontamination listed below should be performed prior to transport and in coordination with Hazmat Guideline 

 	 • If powdered chemical, brush away excess. Remove clothing if possible and place in red biohazard bag (do not transport the bag in the passenger/patient compartment). 

 	 • Irrigate with copious amounts of water or saline ASAP and during transport. 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Initial Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached. 

 	 • Refer to Pain Management Clinical Care Guideline. 

 THERMAL BURNS 

 I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Remove or cool heat source if present (tar, clothing) 

 	 • Apply cool compress dressings on minor burns with sterile saline (do not use ice packs). 

 	 • Apply dry, sterile burn sheet on: 

 		 i. 2° burns greater than 15% of Body Surface Area 
 		 ii. 3° burns 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Initial Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached. 

 	 • Refer to Pain Management Clinical Care Guideline

I. SUCKING CHEST WOUND/OPEN PNEUMOTHORAX 

 	 • Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • Apply occlusive dressing taped on three sides to create flutter valve. 

 	 • If patient deteriorates, remove dressing temporarily to allow air to escape. 

 II. TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX 

 	 • Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached 

 	 • Suspect when patient presents with severe respiratory distress, hypotension, distended neck veins, absent breath sounds on the involved side, and/or tracheal deviation. Also suspect when marked resistance is met while assisting respirations. 

 	 • Pleural Decompression on the affected side. 

 III. PERICARDIAL TAMPONADE 

 	 • Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached 

 	 • Suspect when patient presents with hypotension, distended neck veins, muffled heart tones and good breath sounds bilaterally, or penetrating chest injuries between the right midclavicular line and the left midaxillary line. 

 	 • Fluid Bolus: 250 ml increments of NS while transporting (maximum total infusion 1 liter). 

 IV. FLAIL SEGMENT 

 	 • Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • Splint/support flail segment with soft splinting material 

 	 • Assess for ventilatory compromise. 

 	 • If patient deteriorates, assess for possible pneumothorax. 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV with NS lock attached

I. BASIC CARE 

 	 • Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • Keep patient warm 

 	 • Oxygen: 15 LPM NRB 

 II. ADVANCED CARE 

 	 • Cardiac monitor 

 	 • Pulse Oximetry and Capnography: Apply capnography and monitor respiratory drive. 

 	 • IV: Establish an IV of NS KVO 

 	 • Fluid bolus in 250 ml increments, re-evaluating every 250 ml. Titrate systolic BP > 100 mm Hg. 

 	 • Pain Management: refer to Pain Management Clinical Care Guideline. 

 	 • Ondansetron: 4 mg slow IVP over 2 minutes for nausea and vomiting 

 III. Physician’s Consult: For delayed extrications where one or more extremities is involved and circulation is compromised contact Medical Control for: 

 	 • IV fluids of 1000 ml, followed by 500 ml/hr drip. 

 	 • Sodium Bicarbonate:50 mEq IVP. 

 	 • Constricting bands on affected extremities prior to release.

DECOMPRESSION SICKNESS & DYSBARISM 


 SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS:

• Onset usually within 1 - 3 hours after scuba diving. 
 			 • Severe, throbbing pain involving the muscles, joints, and abdomen. 
 			 • Pruritus and mottling of the skin. 
 			 • Patients with a severe reaction will have CNS and / or respiratory difficulties. 

 I. Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • Position and transport patient in left lateral, head down position. Keep patient warm. 

 II. Transport Destination: Determine and coordinate with the Communications Center for transport arrangements to the closest hyperbaric chamber. 

 	 • If the patient is exhibiting altered mental status, the paramedic should immediately coordinate with the Communications Center and Receiving facility for possible transport arrangements to the closest Hyperbaric Chamber: 

 		  UF Health Shands Gainesville 

 		  Florida Hospital Orlando 

 III. If other significant injuries exist, follow Trauma Transport Protocol or appropriate Clinical Care Guideline.

I. Initial Medical/Trauma Care 

 	 • Care should begin in the water, if appropriate. II. Dry patient: remove wet clothing and protect patient against heat loss and wind chill. Completely dry patient and cover patient with insulated blanket. 

 III. If arrhythmias are present, refer to appropriate Clinical Care Guideline. 

 IV. If patient is hypothermic, refer to Environmental Cold Emergencies Clinical Care Guideline.

ADULT (> 15 years old) near drowning should be considered a medical call unless trauma is suspected. These medical patients should be transported by ground to an initial receiving facility. If trauma is evident, transport to a trauma center via air or ground transport per Trauma Transport Protocol Administrative Policy. 

 PEDIATRIC (< 15 years old) near drowning should be transported to a trauma center, whether the mechanism was trauma or medical via air or ground transport per Trauma Transport Protocol Administrative Policy.
